Late Aptian palaeoclimatic turnovers and volcanism: Insights from a shallow-marine and continental succession of the Apennine carbonate platform, southern Italy

This study reports an integrated facies analysis carried out on a new section from the Upper Aptian of the SE Matese Mts. (Civitella Licinio, northern Campania, S. Italy), which includes several decimeter-to-meter scale lacustrine intervals straddling a meter-scale plant-rich Plattenkalk. These intervals are assigned to the late Gargasian–early Clansayesian by their stratigraphic relationship with the upper Salpingoporella dinarica acme as well as lithologic and biostratigraphic supra-regional key-markers found in the Apennine Carbonate Platform (ApCP), including the Orbitolina Level. We infer that the monogeneric parautochthonous plant remains (Frenelopsis sp.) were deposited in a supratidal-to-paralic coastal mudflat close to a restricted, shallow-marine lagoon, at the verge of an arid–semiarid climatic phase. The Plattenkalk was rapidly replaced by persistent lacustrine lithofacies at the onset of amajor climatic turnover (Glacial Trigger). The overlying shallow-marine deposits are capped by a deeply incised palaeokarstic surface and, in turn, by unconformable middle Clansayesian transgressive shallow-marine deposits. Interlayering of reliable lithologic indicators of palaeoclimate and High-Resolution Event Stratigraphic (HIRES) correlation of the Civitella Licinio succession with the astrochronologically tuned Mt. Faito reference section of the ApCP bring evidence of rapidly fluctuating hydroclimatic conditions (wet and arid phases) in the short (100 ky) and long (400 ky) eccentricity time band. HIRES and astrochronological age assignment to crucial key markers and humid/arid phases at Civitella Licinio permit to further refine the detailed stratigraphy of the Mt. Faito reference section and to assign the upper S. dinarica acme of the ApCP to a numerical age of 118.55– 118.50 My. SEM and EDS analyses document common to abundant windblown volcanic particles (glass shards and sanidine crystals) throughout the Frenelopsis-rich Plattenkalk (~118.3 to ~118.2 My) and the encasing units, especially in the overlying brackish–lacustrine deposits. Palaeogeographic and palaeoclimatic reconstructions suggest that the pyroclastic material was probably transported by northeasterly trade winds from orogenic volcanic centers located within the Dinaridic–Carpatho-Balkan arc–trench system and have been supplied to the ApCP for a time span of ~3My during the Late Aptian. A preliminary tephrostratigraphic correlation of the Upper Aptian volcaniclastic levels of the ApCP with the bentonite levels of the Vocontian Basin is proposed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The spatial and temporal patterns of middle-Cretaceous palaeoclimate evolution are far from being fully understood despite remarkable results (Hay, 2008, 2009; Hay and Floegel, 2012; Chaboureau et al., 2012). Crucial pitfalls in current palaeoclimatic studies are generally represented by: A) paucity of reliable biotic, sedimentary, mineralogical and geochemical indicators of palaeohydrologic conditions; B) incomplete palaeogeographic distribution of data sets; C) lack of
,
suitable, chronostratigraphical calibration of shallow- and deep-water records; and D) only partial comprehension of the global palaeoclimate systemduring rapid phases of greenhouse–icehouse transitions (cf.Hay, 2009; Hasegawa et al., 2012). These problems generally bias the overall predictivity and reliability of General CirculationModels (GCMs) for the Mesozoic as these latter require precise information on a complex set of surface boundary conditions, including the distribution and evolution of vegetation types in specific time intervals (see Sewall et al., 2007). This is the case for the Aptian, an interval of rapid and significant changes of atmospheric pCO2 (Retallack, 2002; Royer, 2006; Li et al., 2014; Wang et al., 2014), temperature (Steuber et al., 2005; Mutterlose et al., 2009; McAnena et al., 2013; Bodin et al., 2015), sea level (Al-Husseini, 2013; Maurer et al., 2013; Bover-Arnal et al., 2014; Haq, 2014), and ocean
geochemistry (Puceat et al., 2005; Wortmann and Chernyavsky, 2007), which all induced towering palaeoclimatic and palaeoceanographic events (Jenkyns, 2010; Föllmi, 2012; Bottini et al., 2015) aswell as drastic biotic and geochemical forcings in the marine (Skelton and Gili, 2012; Erba et al., 2015; Pascual-Cebrian et al., 2016) and continental (Jahren et al., 2001; Suarez et al., 2014) realms. Consistent with these changes, and based on the Upper Aptian continental and shallowmarine deposits of the Apennine Carbonate Platform (ApCP) (southern Italy), Graziano and Raspini (2015) have recently documented repeated shrinkings and expansions of the intertropical, arid and humid palaeoclimatic belts with a well-defined orbital control in the short (100 ky)- and long (400 ky)-eccentricity time bands. These hydroclimatic shifts have been correlated also in a Tethyan framework and provided with numerical ages according to integrated stratigraphic procedures constrained by an astrochronological tuning with Tethyan pelagic reference sections.
Continental deposits of the Aptian are increasingly evaluated as reliable recorders of regional to global palaeoclimatic turnovers and represent useful proxies for investigating the evolution of pCO2, palaeotemperature and water cycle (Heimhofer et al., 2003; Suarez et al., 2011; Rodríguez-López et al., 2012; Li et al., 2013; Ludvigson
et al., 2015; Du et al., 2016). In addition, they concur to upbuild the archive of the Cretaceous continental record, which is the only wellfounded indicator for establishing theworldwide palaeogeographic distribution of climatic belts and their evolution through time (Chumakov et al., 1995; Ziegler et al., 2003; Sewall et al., 2007; Boucot et al., 2013) over a fundamental interval of the Mesozoic greenhouse Earth. Aptian continental deposits of southern Italy represent a valuable source of information for defining the palaeogeography (e.g. Dalla Vecchia, 2008; Zarcone et al., 2010) and palaeoclimatology (Graziano and Raspini, 2015) of the peri-Adriatic area. Furthermore, owing to their peculiar fossiliferous record which includes dinosaurs (e.g. Petti et al., 2008; Sacchi et al., 2009; Citton et al., 2015) and plants (e.g. Bartiromo et al., 2009, 2012a) they bear significant, supra-regional palaeobiogeographical implications.
Recent investigation has emphasized the crucial role of the Aptian terrestrial, shallow- and deep-water fossil record as possible analogs to derive the current and future climate changes (Hay, 2011; Skelton and Gili, 2012; Graziano, 2013; Bottini et al., 2015; Graziano and Raspini, 2015). However, these results augment the need of refining available techniques for high-resolution stratigraphic correlations with which to complement precise palaeoclimatic information in a
palaeogeographic and chronostratigraphic perspective (cf.Graziano and Raspini, 2015). At the moment, for instance, predictive values of the most advanced global palaeoclimatic distribution maps suffer from a limited chronostratigraphic resolution, in the range of several tens of million years (e.g. Boucot et al., 2013), as well as from relatively few and far between palaeogeographic data sets of reliable lithologic indicators (Sewall et al., 2007; Xu et al., 2012). Furthermore, despite remarkable results from isotope chemostratigraphy, physical correlation of continental, shallow- and deep-water Aptian key-markers is still vague, with the result of imprecise understanding of the cause-andeffect relationships underlying their onset and termination as well as palaeonvironmental feedbacks.
Aiming to bridge some of the gaps in knowledge above and to improve the comprehension of the Late Aptian in southern Italy, we describe here the stratigraphic record of a new section from the ApCP exposed at Civitella Licinio, in the SE Matese Mts. (northern Campania, S. Italy). Furthermore, we discuss the related palaeoclimatic implications derived from a variety of stacked continental deposits, yielding windblown pyroclastic fragments, which were deposited during the long-term exposure of large sectors of the ApCP (Graziano and Raspini, 2015). This carbonate platform was located in a crucial palaeogeographic area of the middle Cretaceous Western Tethys, which is poorly constrained by current global palaeoclimatic distribution maps, and may contribute significantly toward refinement of their completeness, and improvement of supra-regional palaeoclimatic models. The correlation of the Civitella Licinio section herein with the astrochronologically-tuned Mt. Faito reference section of the ApCP after Graziano and Raspini (2015) is presented and the derived, high-
resolution palaeoclimatic signal is compared to put forward coherent fluctuations of the regional hydroclimatic conditions. Distinct wet vs arid phases are indicated by interlayering of reliable lithologic indicators, which include a plant-rich Plattenkalk and several lacustrine intervals, up to several meters thick.
Further studies will focus in detail on the palaeoenvironmental and palaeoclimatic implications of the Upper Aptian of the ApCP, which includes remarkable plant-rich continental deposits from nearby sections (see Bravi and Garassino, 1998; Bartiromo et al., 2009, 2012a; Bartiromo, 2013).

sections.heading: 2. Geological setting and stratigraphic outline
sections.text:
The Civitella Licinio section crops out along a country road cut on the side of Il Campo poljie (~1010 m asl), about 1 km NE of Mt. Monaco di Gioia (Fig. 1). This relief is part of a regional, NE plunging carbonate monocline in the southeastern sector of theMatese Rangewhere nearby sections with Upper Aptian continental and paralic deposits have been described (Bravi and Mega, 1999; Bartiromo et al., 2012a) (Figs. 1, 2). The section is part of an approximately 3500 m thick succession of Upper Triassic–Lower Cretaceous shallow-water limestones belonging to the ApCP, first studied by Catenacci et al. (1963). It is worth noting, however, that a recent reappraisal has hypothesized a derivation of the Matese shallow-water succession from the Late Pliocene exhumation of a formerly buried slice of the Apulia carbonate platform (Carannante et al., 2009). Regardless of these different palaeogeographic views, neither the analytical procedure and stratigraphic conclusions nor the correlation between the sections
herein is biased owing to the corresponding palaeolatitude of the platforms in concern (Fig. 3).
The ApCP was a Middle Triassic–Early Miocene palaeogeographic unit, about 4500 m thick, which originated from the early rifting of the southern Tethyan continental margin (D'Argenio and Alvarez, 1980). Starting in the Early Jurassic, it was surrounded by deep-water pelagic basins: the Umbria–Marche (UMB) and Lagonegro Basins (Fig. 3). However, recent palaeogeographic models envisage a southward attachment of the ApCP to the Gondwana mainland (Zarcone et al., 2010), as also supported by the palaeontological and palaeoecological implications of several dinosaur ichnocoenoses and fossil remains in the middle Cretaceous shallow-water carbonates of central and southern Italy (Nicosia et al., 2007; Dalla Vecchia, 2008; Dal Sasso and Maganuco, 2011; Citton et al., 2015).
During the Aptian, theApCPwas located at a palaeolatitude of ~25°N (Stampfli and Kozur, 2006) in the arid climate belt of the Western Tethys and about 600 km south of the mid latitude, warm humid belt (Ziegler et al., 2003) (Fig. 3). Up until the Early Cretaceous the ApCP was a chlorozoan carbonate factory, whichwas replaced in the Late Cretaceous by a foramol open shelf, largely dwelled by rudist assemblages (Carannante et al., 1997, 1999). The ApCP was finally incorporated into the southern Apennine fold-and-thrust belt following Early Miocene orogenic tectonics and the Late Miocene opening of the Tyrrhenian back-arc basin (e.g.Menardi Noguera and Rea, 2000).
The ApCP underwent multiple, long-term exposures in the Late Aptian–Turonian p.p.with local development of bauxite and lacustrine or evaporite deposits, up to several meters thick, depending on the variable hydroclimatic conditions during this time interval (Carannante et al., 2009; Simone et al., 2012; Graziano and Raspini, 2015).
The Upper Aptian–lowermost Albian of the ApCP in the SE Matese Mts. (e.g. Carannante et al., 2006, 2009; Ruberti et al., 2013) yields some Plattenkalk and lithographic intervals with exceptionally rich and diversified continental fossil assemblages including plants, crustaceans, fishes, lizards, crocodilomorphs and dinosaurs (D'Argenio, 1963; Bravi and Garassino, 1998; Bartiromo et al., 2006, 2012a; Evans
et al., 2006; Dal Sasso and Maganuco, 2011; Buscalioni et al., 2011; Bartiromo, 2013). On the whole, their stratigraphic and palaeonvironmental interpretation, especially that concerning the well-known, lowermost Albian Pietraroja Plattenkalk (which is exposed at only 7 km north of the Civitella Licinio section), is currently debated (Carannante et al., 2006; Dal Sasso and Maganuco, 2011; Bartiromo, 2013). The Civitella Licinio section also includes a plant-rich Plattenkalk as well as a lacustrine interval, which are roughly correlatable with the continental deposits mentioned above and with the Upper Aptian Plattenkalk at La Peschera and Mt. Cigno. These latter, containing rich assemblages of fishes (Bravi and Mega, 1999) and terrestrial plants (Bartiromo et al., 2012a), crop out only 3–4 km southeastward of the Civitella Licinio section (Figs. 1, 2) and, thus, represent a promising case for detailed stratigraphic and palaeoenvironmental studies with which to derive the palaeoecologic and palaeoclimatic framework of the ApCP emerged lands during the Late Aptian.
The Civitella Licinio section yields one of the two Salpingoporella dinarica acmes which straddle the Orbitolina Level of the ApCP (Di Lucia et al., 2012). This level represents a supra-regional key-marker, which is indicative of a reduced carbonate sedimentation rate due to drastic environmental perturbators, including high nutrient supply, cooling, and intensified monsoonal activity (Raspini, 2012). More particularly, the Orbitolina Level has been considered correlative with part of the Fallot Oceanic Anoxic Event (OAE), thus identifying a reference platform-to-basin marker in the Upper Aptian of the Tethyan ocean (Raspini, 2012; Graziano and Raspini, 2015). The Upper Aptian Civitella Licinio section encompasses a time interval whichwas characterized by drastic climatic changes and extensional tectonics during a long-term, glacioeustatically induced subaerial exposure of large sectors of the ApCP as well as many other neritic domains worldwide (Graziano and Raspini, 2015). Hence, it provides further stratigraphic and palaeoenvironmental elements for improving our comprehension of the Late Aptian world in the western Tethys.

sections.heading: 3. Material and methods
sections.text:
The section has been studied in the field at a centimeter resolution using a 10× hand-lens and sampled at 10–15 cm intervals. Several polished slabs (up to 10 × 15 cm) were investigated to characterize biosedimentary fabric, composition, and the main sedimentary structures of coarse bioclastic as well as plant-rich beds. About 90 thin sections (4 × 6.5 cm) have been studied semi-quantitatively to support sedimentologic, biostratigraphic and palaeoecologic interpretations as well as to decipher biofacies and palaeoenvironmental evolutions.
Hundreds of slabs retaining abundant plant remains and wood fragments have been collected from the Civitella Licinio Plattenkalk during several 2014–2015 excavations. Plant remains are represented mainly by impressions (imprints, 2-dimensional, devoid of organic matter) and, secondarily, by isolated fragments preserved as carbonaceous compressions (3-dimensional, with organic material) in the very finegrained lime matrix forming sheet-like layers. The plant remains analyzed so far retain fragments of variously preserved, small-sized cuticles (a perfect replica of the plant epidermis; Barclay et al., 2007) which, however, are often oxidized, making their study difficult. All slabs studied display fragmented or entire cylindrical segments bearing badly preserved epidermal features. Their observation by 10× handlens has revealed cellular elements of the cuticle disposed in rows. Problematic preparation of some small-sized cuticle fragments by means of acid techniques has prompted us to mount them directly on stubs for SEM analyses with, unfortunately, no useful information so far.
The application of the peel technique with low viscosity collodion (see Bartiromo et al., 2012a) gave no results as the epidermal components are generally destroyed when the collodion film is stripped off. Hence, preliminarily taxonomic identificationwas carried out following a stereomicroscope observation; photomicrographswere taken using a Nikon Coolpix 990 camera.
Following microscopic analysis, selected portions of the Plattenkalk samples were digested in a 37% hydrochloric acid solution to remove the calcareous matrix surrounding debris of plants and invertebrates. The fragments were subsequently macerated in the oxidizing Schulze's reagent (KClO3 + HNO3). Adhering siliceous material was removed by immersion in 40% hydrofluoric acid. Plant debris has been prepared
for SEM analysis, but palaeobotanical results represent the object of a further contribution.
SEM analysis of about 25 bulk samples, using a JEOL JSM-5310 instrument at the Università degli Studi di Napoli Federico II, has been performed throughout the Plattenkalk, at a dm spacing, and in the encasing units. Energy-Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) has been

Crucial biostratigraphic and lithologic key-markers of the Civitella Licinio section have been correlated with the High-Resolution Event Stratigraphic (HIRES) framework of the ApCP following a refinement of the Mt. Faito reference section after Graziano and Raspini (2015).

sections.heading: 4.1. Lithostratigraphy and facies analysis
sections.text:
Based on the stratal pattern, facies analysis, and stratigraphic distribution of specific biosedimentary features, the investigated section, ~10.5 m thick, has been subdivided into the lithostratigraphic Units D and E by reference to those of the Mt. Faito section with which the Civitella Licinio section is correlated (see Section 5.2). According to the same approach, Unit D herein has been subdivided further into units D1–D6 (Fig. 4). Given the prominent palaeoenvironmental and palaeoclimatic significance of the meter-scale Plattenkalk found in the lower part of the section (Figs. 4, 5), the stratigraphic description of this latter has been reported accordingly (Sections 4.1.1–3). The microstratigraphic analysis of sedimentary textures, biosedimentary features and early diagenetic overprint has allowed the recognition of several lithofacies associations holding distinct palaeoenvironmental significances: 1 — bivalve limestones with intraclasts (open shallow lagoon); 2 — Salpingoporella limestones (restricted shallow lagoon); 3 — laminated limestones (brackish lagoon to tidal flat); 4 — charophyteostracod limestones andmarly limestones, and greenmarls (lake-coastal marsh); and 5 — plant-rich limestones; cryptalgal limestones, and calcareous crusts (supratidal-to-paralic coastal mudflat). Table 1 summarizes the main bio-sedimentary features of the lithofacies A–O recognized in the Civitella Licinio section (Fig. 4) together with their associations (1–5) and the inferred depositional environments.
Grain-supported, intra-bioclastic limestones with sharp and erosional bases form episodic, normally graded, mm-to-cm thick intercalations in nearly all the lithofacies above (mostly in Units D3 and D4) (Fig. 4). The related intraclastic and bioclastic grains (cm-sized oncoids are locally present) exhibit different shapes, roundness and sorting. These deposits are interpreted as high-energy sediments mobilized by storm events in subtidal to supratidal settings (e.g. Aigner, 1985) or associated with a relative sea-level rise (ravinement deposits) (e.g. Husinec and Read, 2011).

These intervals are overlain by decametric lenses and layers of greenish marls and shaley marls, 5–35 cm-thick, containing abundant charophyte gyrogonites and stems aswell as thin-shelled, unornamented ostracods (lithofacies K; Fig. 7). Thin (up to a few cm) and discontinuous breccias with small-sized marly intraclasts in a coarsegrained bioclastic matrix locally occur at the base of the cycles (Fig. 6B). We interpret these sediments as ravinement deposits and/or transgressive washovers (Fig. 4). In the middle part of Unit D1, the charophyte-rich sediments encase a dark, organic carbon-rich calcareous palaeosol, several cm thick, yielding a biogenic laminar calcrete crust at the base of a calcitized hardpan with abundant glaebules and common rizholithes (Fig. 6C–D) (lithofacies L).
The uppermost charophyte-rich layer of Unit D1 is sharply overlain by a distinct bed, 10 cm thick, with a very densely packed, monospecific assemblage of S. dinarica (lithofacies E; Figs. 6E, 7) exhibiting the topotypical calcification pattern, i.e., white, radial-fibrous calcite with a dark inner layer (“type A” calcification sensu Carras et al., 2006) (Fig. 6F). These algae, which float in a dense micropeloidal matrix and are rock-forming in most of the bed, display sparse evidence of a winnowing-derived lamination indicating the influence of low-energy bottom currents and/or waves (Fig. 6E). The S. dinarica acme declines slowly and, about 25 cm above its base, grades to microbialitic, finely laminated wackestone/packstone with abundant Salpingoporella sp., frequent Thaumatoporella sp. and ostracods.
About 15 cmof thinly-laminatedmicrobialites, barren of fossils,with red-stained anastomosing surfaces and local desiccation cracks (lithofacies M; Fig. 8) sharply overlie the Unit D1 whose uppermost part exhibits cm-sized, closely spaced cavities with lime and marly polychrome infills. The interval above is followed by two beds, 1.15 m thick, of rather homogeneous, micropeloidalmudstone andwackestone containing some benthic foraminifers (miliolids, P. infracretacea, D. hahounerensis and Vercorsella sp.), rare S. dinarica and sparse solitary corals with millimetric microbial encrustations (Unit D2) (lithofacies I, F, and D). Common to frequent sponge spicules in a mudstone with sparse miliolids and frequent desiccation cracks characterize the top of Unit D2 (Fig. 4). Sponge remains are calcitized and exhibit shape and internal features of formerly siliceous spicules (e.g. a narrowcentral canal) (Fig. 6G).

sections.heading: 4.1.2. The Civitella Licinio plant-rich Plattenkalk
sections.text:
The investigated Plattenkalk (Unit D3) is 0.95 m-thick and sharply overlies a gently wavy surface cut on top of micropeloidal limestones of the underlying Unit D2 (Fig. 9). The Plattenkalk yields abundant plant remains and consists of a lower and an upper interval, 64 and 31 cm thick, respectively; it is made up of very thin to thin bed sets of grayish to brownish mudstone and wackestone with rare interlayers of grayish marly mudstone (lithofacies O, N). Fine-grained limestones of the lower Plattenkalk are grayish, on average finer and thinner with respect to those of the upper interval (Figs. 10, 11). Regardless of the stratigraphic position, the Plattenkalk beds are evenly laminated. Laminae display a remarkable lateral continuity with only minor interruptions by erosional surfaces or bioturbation activity (Fig. 11A–B). They are sensibly finer and thinner (up to 2 mm) in the lower Plattenkalk and considerably coarser and thicker (up to 10 mm) in the upper one (Fig. 12) (Fig. 11C–D). Intraclasts, up to 5 mm large, are prevailingly sub-rounded to sub-angular mud chips (Fig. 11D), barren of fossils or yielding fine plant debris, and either structureless or faintly laminated. Moreover, abraded bioclasts are constituted generally by small-sized S. dinarica specimens (Fig. 11E) and recrystallized miliolids as well as rare P. infracretacea. A low-relief, channel-like structure with a bio-intraclastic sedimentary infill, similar to the one described above, is present at the base of the upper Plattenkalk.
Plant remains are set parallel to bedding planes and randomly arranged (Fig. 13A), especially in the lower Plattenkalk. Their preservation degree and abundance gradually increase toward the upper part of the Plattenkalk, which yields the most abundant and largest plant remains (Fig. 11F–G), including branched specimens up to ~10 cm large (Fig. 13B), aswell as small fragments of badly preserved cuticle. Impressions and ill-preserved compressions of disarticulated (Fig. 13A) and articulated (Fig. 13B) vegetative segments represent the bulk of the plant fossils. Some specimens retain epidermal features (Fig. 14A–B) that are difficult to be observed in detail; nonetheless, they are useful for gross taxonomical purpose (see Section 4.2.1). No reproductive structure has been found. Calcareous beds contain also large (Fig. 14C) and fusainized axes (Fig. 14D) up to 10 cm long and 1 cm wide. Fusainized
materials are easily recognizable by their shape and silky luster but also because when rubbed with a finger they release a fine black dust.
In a thin section, the plant remains are 0.5 to 10 mm in length and 0.1 to 0.5 mm in thickness, on average, and appear as flattened fragments parallel to bedding (Fig. 11F–G). Common to abundant detrital grains, 0.1–0.5 mm large, are also present; their porphyroskelic microfabric, made up of very fine-grained equant debris, and physical relationshipwith characteristically “foliaceous” large plant remains suggest that they derive from the comminution of these latter (Fig. 11H). In many cases, however, slightwinnowing of the equant debris has resulted in a very finely laminated microfabric (Fig. 11B).
Rare, small-sized (~1 × 0.5 mm) and well preserved fragments of crustaceans have been found (Fig. 15). They bear numerous setae, up to 80 μm long and 8–10 μm wide at the base, which are elongated and finely sculptured longitudinally, thus indicating a considerable preservation potential of the lime matrix.
Interestingly, very fine-grained and common to frequent non-carbonate grains are scattered in the background lime matrix. Their morphological and compositional analyses, pointing to a volcanic origin, are presented in Section 4.3 and discussed in Sections 5.2–3.

sections.heading: 4.1.3. The section above the Plattenkalk
sections.text:
The Plattenkalk is sharply overlain by a rather homogeneous interval of shallowmarine to paralic wackestone tomudstone, 1.2m-thick (Unit D4) (Fig. 10), containing small-sized miliolids, ostracods and, in same levels, sparse, abraded or in situ charophyte gyrogonites and stems (lithofacies H; Figs. 4, 16A–C). A thin-bedded interval made up of a fine-grained intraclastic packstone, sourced from the underlying Plattenkalk, is present at the base of this interval pointing to amoderate reworking at the onset of a relative sea level rise. Black pebbles have also been found pointing to coastal erosion of preferentially cemented and blackened paralic sediments (cf. Strasser, 1984). Emersion-related features in the form of thin, discontinuous veneers of greenish clay resting on gently eroded karstic surfaces are scattered in the indistinctly bedded Unit D4.
The section continues with 1.42 m of structureless, thin-to-medium bedded, grayish to greenish mudstone and marly mudstone with common to abundant charophyte gyrogonites and stems aswell as articulated and disarticulated ostracods with unornamented shells (lithofacies J; Fig. 16D–F) (Unit D5). Rare, mm-scale intercalations of shallow-water, fine-grained deposits have also been found, typically in the lowermost and uppermost parts of this Unit. They are made up of sparse, smallsized S. dinarica and benthonic foraminifers, thin-shelled bivalve remains and small-sized black pebbles. This interlayering exhibits rather gradual facies changeswith no detectable evidence of erosional surfaces
(Fig. 16E). Throughout Unit D5, charophyte- and ostracod-rich deposits display several surfaces with distinct traces of ephemeral subaerial exposures in the form of desiccation cracks with geopetal infill (Fig. 16F) and palaeokarstic features marked by veneers of shaley marls with rhizolites that penetrate and alter host mudstones for several mm.
The overlyingUnit D6 is about 2.8m thick. The lower 1.20m consists mostly of wackestone with benthonic foraminifers, which rapidly evolves to peloidal packstone with benthonic foraminifers and, locally, abundant requieniids up to 5 cm large (lithofacies C). This part of the section is crudely bedded and displays several thin veneers of greenish
shaley marls, which infill smoothed palaeokarstic surfaces. The upper 1.60 m of the Unit D6 is made up of Chondrodonta-rich coarse-grained deposits, with minor requieniids (lithofacies B; Fig. 16G), resting on a deeply scoured erosive surface. Chondrodonta, which are up to 10 cm in size and locally accompanied by requieniids ≤3 cm large, float in a matrix of packstone with benthonic foraminifers (mostly miliolids and verneulinids). Normally graded, intra-bioclastic rudstone to wellsorted coarse-grained grainstone with erosive bases are frequently intercalated at the base. They contain Chondrodonta debris, benthonic foraminifers, S. dinarica, small gastropods and sparse solitary corals along with intraclasts, up to 3 cm in size, pointing to appreciable reworking processes (Fig. 17). In the uppermost Unit D6, corals have also been found together with Chondrodonta floating in a matrix of grainstone to packstone and wackestone with benthonic foraminifers and small-sized green algae.
Chondrodonta and requieniid shells of the upper Unit D6 are frequently leached; molds have been subsequently filled by reddish-topink clay and silt, pointing to the development of early palaeokarstic features that penetrate ~1 m into the underlying, extensively altered shallow-marine carbonates. This palaeokarstic interval is characterized also by discontinuous collapse breccias and an intricate system of dissolution, sheet-like cavities, several dm-long and up to 2–3 cm in height, with multiphase cements and reddish to pink clayey infills (Fig. 18).
Unconformable, indistinctly bedded and grain-supported shallowmarine bio-intraclastic limestones, some meters thick, with bivalve debris, rare S. dinarica, P. infracretacea, D. hahounerensis, Vercorsella sp. and miliolids end the section (Unit E) (lithofacies A).

sections.heading: 4.2. Bio-chronostratigraphy of remarkable key markers and plant palaeontology
sections.text:
The Aptian biostratigraphy for the ApCP is based on benthonic foraminifer and dasycladalean biozones that have been described in detail and updated recently by Chiocchini et al. (2012) and Di Lucia et al. (2012), the latter calibrating total ranges and acmes of selected index fossils to carbon and strontium isotope chemostratigraphy.

The Civitella Licinio section is characterized by the co-occurrence of D. hahounerensis and S. dinarica thus pointing to an Aptian age, according to Di Lucia et al. (2012). Further microfossils characterizing the whole section are Triploporella sp., P. infracretacea, Spiroloculina sp., and Thaumatoporella sp., along with miliolids (Triloculina sp. and Quinqueloculina sp.) and textularids. Additional index microfossils are Nezzazata aff. isabellae, Pfenderina aff. globosa, Vercorsella laurentii, Pseudolituonella aff. conica and Salpingoporella sp., below the Plattenkalk, as well as Salpingoporella urladanasi and Vercorsella arenata above the Plattenkalk. Apart from D. hahounerensis, S. dinarica and S. urladanasi, the upper part of the section yields a poor diagnostic fossil assemblage, which is largely dominated by bivalves (mostly Chondrodonta with minor requienids). The remarkable lack of the index fossils Voloshinoides murgensis, Palorbitolina lenticularis and Triploporella marsicana implies that the Lower Aptian is not comprised in the studied section (cf. Husinec and Sokač, 2006; Schroeder et al., 2010; Chiocchini et al., 2012).
The lower part of the Civitella Licinio section yields one of the two acmes of S. dinarica (Figs. 4, 6E–F) that straddle the Orbitolina Level in the Upper Aptian of the ApCP; this level, which marks the first occurrence of Mesorbitolina texana and Mesorbitolina parva in the southern Apennines (e.g. Cherchi et al., 1978), has been assigned to the late Gargasian and to an astrochronologically-derived age of 118.80– 118.70 My (Graziano and Raspini, 2015). Hence, according to the biostratigraphic data and correlations above, a Late Aptian (late Gargasian) age is assigned to Unit D with the notable exception of (upper?) Unit D5 and Unit D6. Faito section implies that the upper Unit D5 and Unit D6 at Civitella Licinio would fall in the early Clansayesian (see Section 5.2). Consequently, we infer that the Gargasian–Clansayesian boundary should be positioned within the lacustrine deposits of Unit D5 (Fig. 4).

sections.heading: 4.2.1. Plattenkalk plant macroremains
sections.text:
The dimensions of plant specimens vary from ~3 mm (fragmented internodes) to ~10 cm (branched shoots). The branchlets seem to be disposed in one plane whereas the order of branching is not clear. The shoots are segmented and show a central vascular bundle. The internode length varies between 4 and 10 mm whereas the segment width is 1.3–2.4mm. There are no suture lines along the leaf sheath and the internodes bear whorls of two (opposite and decussate) or three triangular free tips (Fig. 13C). The free part of the leaves is triangular in shape and measures ~1 mm in length. Leaves have an acute apex and are adpressed to the axis.
Epidermal features are difficult to be observed as the specimens investigated so far show only poorly preserved cuticular features. The epidermal cells, polygonal–rectangular to square in shape, do not exceed 50 μm in length and ~30 μm in width, and are arranged in more or less well-defined rows running parallel to the long axis of the internode (Fig. 14A). The anticlinal walls of the epidermal cells are ~8 μm thick. The stomatal complexes are ill preserved and, hence, their morphology is difficult to be clearly assessed; nonetheless, they are arranged inwelldefined longitudinal rows (7–10 permm) (Fig. 14B) which are separated by 2–3 epidermal cells.
The studied specimens present amacroscopical architecture (e.g. cylindrical leafy stems) andmicro-morphological characters (e.g. stomatal complexes arranged in rows), which allow their attribution to the extinct conifer family Cheirolepidiaceae Takhtajan, 1963. Based on differences in shoot morphology (Tosolini et al., 2015), Cheirolepidiaceae are subdivided in the so-called frenelopsids (predominantly a whorled phyllotaxis) and non-frenelopsids (leaves borne in a spiral arrangement). sections.heading: 4.3. SEM and EDS analyses
sections.text:
The Plattenkalk groundmass is quite homogeneous as far as composition and microfabric are concerned (Figs. 11, 20). It is made up of a normally structureless mosaic of equant to tabular micrite crystals, 1– 5 μm large. Contacts among crystal faces are randomand at different angles while eventual inclusions or relict structures are lacking (Fig. 20G).
These micropetrographic features point to a primary origin of the micrite crystals (cf. Retallack, 2001). Locally, micrite crystals form empty aggregates, up to ~10 μm large, that resemble the overgrowth of authigenic micrite crystals around a spheroidal nucleous (bacterially-induced structures?) (Fig. 19). Some subspherical and tuberose calcareous glaebules (nodules) (e.g. Dean and Fouch, 1983; Retallack, 2001), exhibiting an internal massive texture of microsparite and outer, well definedmargins, have been also observed. Rare pollen grains are also present.
Clayey veneers, up to few tens of μm thick, occur in the background micrite of the lowermost and upper parts of the Plattenkalk (Fig. 20B). In these stratigraphic intervals, relatively abundant clay minerals also coat discrete micrite crystals, thus forming a characteristic mixture of mineral phases. Their abundance, however, is very low as a qualitative estimate of the clay content does not exceed 2–3%. sections.heading: 5.1.1. The section beneath the Plattenkalk
sections.text:
The fossil association and the early diagenetic overprint of the cyclically organized subtidal–supratidal carbonate deposits of Unit D1 suggest a deposition in inner lagoonal settings with restricted circulation; this setting was subjected to repeated ephemeral up to relatively prolonged subaereal exposures followed by episodic high-energy events related to sea ingressions. The green marly interlayers and lenses with abundant charophyte remains and less common ostracods capping the depositional cycles (Fig. 7) represent the sedimentary product of fresh and/or brackish water environments in the form of ponds or ephemeral lakes (e.g. Dean and Fouch, 1983). The centimetric laminar calcrete with evident rhizoconcretions/rhizolites (e.g.Alonso-Zarza et al., 1998)which punctuates the middle Unit D1, immediately below the uppermost lacustrine interlayer, indicates an episode of semi-arid hydroclimatic conditions (Esteban and Klappa, 1983; Retallack, 2001; Philippe et al., 2010). It is not clear whether this palaeosol, that closely resembles the calcified mats of an horizontal root system (cf. Wright et al., 1988), was deposited in a semi-arid context or, alternatively, could be interpreted as the result of an episodic subaerial exposure in a marginal lacustrine setting during a low position of the palaeo-water table. Nonetheless, both these interpretations suggest an episodic, drastic decrease of fresh water availability on the emerged platform (see Section 5.2).
The following S. dinarica acme, which preserves in its uppermost part the gradual disappearance of the related climax conditions (Fig. 6E), sharply overlies the uppermost lacustrine sediments in Unit D1. Raspini (2012) has argued that a remarkable long-term lowering of Mg/Ca ratio in seawater and a concomitant ocean acidification event could have favored the bloom of this opportunistic, low-Mg calcitic green alga. The S. dinarica acme passes very gradually to micropeloidal limestones, which likely herald the increasing biosedimentary role exerted by microbial communities in the overlying Unit D2. The sedimentary, diagenetic and petrographic features at the base of this unit (Fig. 8) are related to condensation and/or omission processes at multiple scales, and suggest a relatively prolonged subaereal exposure under arid–semiarid conditions (cf. Husinec and Read, 2011). The overlying micropeloidal/microbial muddy deposits of Unit D2 display a low-diversity and impoverished biota, which is indicative of restricted, subtidal up to low intertidal environments. This guild could be indicative of extreme environments which were characterized by low sedimentation rate (Rameil et al., 2010), and elevated temperature coupled to increasing sea water acidification, nutrient supply (Huck et al., 2010; Bover-Arnal et al., 2011) and, likely, elevated salinity. Solitary corals are typically azooxanthellate, hence heterotrophic deepwater organisms (Barbeitos et al., 2010), which may thrive in stressed, shallow-water settings following a significant increase of suspended particulate organic matter (Anthony and Fabricius, 2000) and temperature (Jokiel et al., 2008). Heterotrophy also enhances the resistance of several corals to the physiological effects of sea-water acidification andwarming (Edmunds, 2011). As a consequence, wemay hypothesize that Unit D2 was deposited during a remarkable warming event under saline, mesotrophic and possibly acidified conditions. Specifically, the genetic relation ofmesotrophic and acidified conditions in the restricted and extremely shallow deposits of Unit D2 could be related to the environmental pollution caused by volcanic ashes (see Section 5.3).
Such a scenario seems to be upheld by the sudden and rather anomalous flourishment of siliceous sponges in the nearshore, restricted and warm-water embayment of the uppermost Unit D2, just beneath the subaerial Plattenkalk (Fig. 9). With only very few exceptions, in fact, extant siliceous sponges are considered to thrive in deep and cold depositional environments (e.g. Gammon and James, 2001), similarly to their fossil counterparts (e.g. Beauchamp and Desrochers, 1997), unless the specific ecologic prerequisites for their proliferation in shallow-marine settings are afforded (e.g. sluggish run-off supplying fine-grained sediments, abundant nutrients and dissolved silica from a low-gradient inland; Gammon et al., 2000; Gammon and James, 2001). This was, for instance, the case of theWestern Australia tropical shelf where a prolific siliceous sponge growth occurred during the Late Eocene (James and Bone, 2000). In near-shore settings, sources of elevated, dissolved and highly reactive silica for biological fixation may be due to oceanic upwelling (e.g. Maliva et al., 1989), riverine input, fallout of volcanic ash, or their combinations (discussion in James and Bone, 2000), and windblown quartzose dust (Cecil, 2004). Concerning the Upper Aptian of Civitella Licinio, we rule out a source of silica from rivers, ocean upwellings or eolian quartzose dust. In fact, we infer that rivers could not have formed on the arid, incipiently emerged Late Aptian ApCP (see also Section 5.2), nor this latter yielded, at that time, exposed crystalline rocks or volcaniclastic deposits for long-termweathering. Furthermore, Unit D2 lacks the typical biotic assemblages of neritic areas undergoing ecologic forcings by upwelled cold and nutrient-rich waters (e.g. coralline red algae, mollusks, barnacles, bryozoans, and brachiopods; e.g. Carannante et al., 1988; James, 1997; Mutti and Hallock, 2003; Michel et al., 2011). Finally, the northeasterly trade wind pattern of the boreal Aptian tropics hampered an eventual supply of siliceous dust from deserts as it connected the ApCP with the temperate, mid-latitude Laurasian regions, which were under the influence of persisting humid conditions. As matter of fact, southern Spain, i.e. the closest erg-like desert (Rodríguez-López et al., 2012) was out of the trade wind route for the ApCP (see Section 5.3). Hence, both direct and indirect evidences suggest that a supply of windblown volcaniclastic material to the shallow lagoon of the ApCP fostered the flourishment of siliceous sponges as well as their early calcification (cf. Neuweiler and Burdige, 2005) and, possibly, of microbially encrusted solitary corals in the upper Unit D2 through a sustained fertilization of sea water by particulate organic matter coupled with increasing acidification. sections.heading: 5.1.2. The Civitella Licinio Plattenkalk
sections.text:
Plant remains found so far in the Plattenkalk belong exclusively to the extinct conifer genus Frenelopsis having segmented shoots with
reduced leaves forming “a collar around the stem” (Tosolini et al., 2015). The extinct conifer family Cheirolepidiaceae was an important component of the Mesozoic flora (Alvin, 1982; Watson, 1988) and Frenelopsis, with 20 species described so far (Gomez et al., 2014; Batten et al., 2014) and a remarkable literature (see Bartiromo, 2013, for a synthesis), can be referred to as the best-known genus of this family. The plants studied display the “classic” xeromorphic macromorphological adaptations (Watson, 1988; Watson and Alvin, 1996; Thévenard et al., 2005) such as photosynthetic stems, deciduous shoots and reduced leaves. Frenelopsis and Pseudofrenelopsis exhibit extreme xeromorphism (Spicer et al., 1993) pointing to growth in dry conditions or adaptation to physiological difficulties in the uptake or internal transport of water (Watson and Alvin, 1996; Haworth and McElwain, 2008). Retallack (2009) pointed out that xeromorphism is an adaptation to dry climate. Frenelopsids
