1999). The presence of xeromorphic features in the material from Civitella Licinio is typical of plants inhabiting terrestrial environments highly influenced by marine or haline conditions (Moreau et al., 2015) and/or by volcanic inputs (Haworth and McElwain, 2008; Bartiromo et al., 2012b, 2013).
The observed monogeneric character of the plant assemblage from Civitella Licinio could be due to different reasons. Cuticles of Frenelopsis have a relatively large preservation potential (Mösle et al., 1998) with respect to other types of plant cuticles such as ferns (Kerp and Krings, 1999),which could have thus undergone a complete decay during taphonomic and diagenetic processes. However, we rule out this hypothesis owing to the parautochthonous nature of the plant remains from Civitella Licinio where growing conditions were highly unfavorable owing to the inferred salt-loaded soil (see below and Section 5.2). Frenelopsis is considered a salt tolerant plant and is reminiscent of some extant angiosperm such as Salicornia, a salt marsh (Watson, 1988) flourishing plant (Glenn et al., 1978; El-Magsodi and Haddoud, 2011). Xeromorphic features of these plants possibly favored the colonization of this type of environment and represented an advantage to cope with the deleterious effects resulting from the volcanic ash falls
(cf. Section 5.3) (see Archangelsky et al., 1995). Obviously, plant growth during the deposition of the Civitella Licinio Plattenkalk would have benefitted from the presence of volcanic material in that volcanic ash is a suitable medium for providing plant with physical support, essential nutrients and water availability (Shoji et al., 1993). Moreover, volcanic particles could have enhanced plant fossil preservation (e.g. Kovar-Eder et al., 2001; García Massini and Jacobs, 2011) due to their chemical and physical function as encapsulating sediments (Jiang et al., 2011).
Based on the sedimentary, petrographic and palaeobotanical features above we interpret the calcareous Civitella Licinio Plattenkalk as amultiphase carbonate aridisol (see below). This latter is normally considered to be produced by microbial consortia and/or weathering, and flushing down the profile, of very fine-grained dust of feldspar (cf. Retallack, 2001). However, the definite source of the primary carbonate mud of the studied Plattenkalk remains unclear as the observed groundmassmicrite crystals lack the typical rod-like habit of organic precursors (e.g. Loisy et al., 1999) and distinct traces of carbonate fixing microorganisms are somewhat sparse (see Section 4.3) (Fig. 19).
The excellent preservation of K-feldspar crystals in the Frenelopsisrich Plattenkalk lends further support to the occurrence of persisting
arid climate conditions during its deposition; salinity, however, did not reach the calcium sulfate precipitation field, given the absence of evaporites in the whole Plattenkalk. It is also worth noting that pedogenic carbonates as well as lithographic limestones have long been related to arid/semi-arid environments (cf. Oost and De Boer, 1994; Tabor and Myers, 2015).
Based on the following sedimentological and taphonomical lines of evidence, it is interpreted here that the lower plant-rich Plattenkalk was deposited in a sheltered, arid supratidal area located close to the sea: 1) very fine grained micrite barren of in situ marine biota; 2) preservation of laminae due to scarce bioturbation; 3) inland transport as thin bedded storm layers of shallow-marine sediments; 4) massive occurrence of terrestrial plants (Frenelopsis sp.); and 5) parautochthonous deposition of the Frenelopsis remains. By contrast, the upper Plattenkalk was deposited in a very restricted, paralic environment which was much closer to the sea as demonstrated by the more frequent, thicker and proximal S. dinarica- and miliolid-bearing storm layers and wash-overs sourced by an inland migrating, inner shallow-marine lagoon. Although the upper Plattenkalk testifies to the development of a subtle transgressive trend, the paralic environment was still dominated by subaerial conditions as indicated by the prevailing palaeosol micrite, the presence of large fusain fragments which indicate a very reduced transport, if any (Scott, 2010), and the parautochthonous deposition of the extremely abundant Frenelopsis remains (Section 4.2.1).

sections.heading: 5.1.3. The section above the Plattenkalk
sections.text:
The mud-supported, deposits of Unit D4 yield scattered benthic foraminifers, charophytes and black pebbles as well as frequent subaerial exposure surfaces. They are indicative of very shallow-marine to brackish settings which were occasionally subjected to meteoric diagenesis leading to distinct, early palaeokarstic features.We do not knowwhether the observed black pebbles imply eroded paralic sediments which were impregnated by organic matter from decayed algae or from burnt terrestrial plants (cf. Strasser, 1984). In several cases, the latter option seems to be the most plausible owing to the presence of the Frenelopsis-rich Plattenkalk and the related fusainized material just beneath Unit D4 (Figs. 13A, 14D).
The overlying, rather homogeneous greenish marls and lime marls with abundant charophytes and ostracods of Unit D5 suggest the gradual establishment of a persisting lacustrine settingwhich favored the intense leaching of K-feldspar crystals (Fig. 22). The lacustrine environment was nourished episodically with storm washovers from brackish, coastal lagoons which were inhabited by impoverished extremophiles (e.g., S. dinarica with small-sized and badly calcitized skeletons and thin, small-sized miliolids). We hypothesize that the episodic depletions of charophyte stems and/or gyrogoniteswithinUnit D5 (Fig. 4) might be related to specific environmental stressors (e.g. increasing salinity and/or nutrient budget, high Mg/Ca ratio, decreasing fresh-water supply) whichmay have affected these fresh-water macrophytes, and their reproductive strategies, as in the case of their extant counterparts (Soulié-Märsche, 2008; Apolinarska et al., 2011). This would be compatible with the deposition of Unit D5 in highly unstable littoral and supra-littoral lacustrine environments and the observed emersions as well as repeated, although ephemeral, encroachments of seawater (Fig. 16E). Unit D5 is replaced very gradually by transgressive, Chondrodonta-bearing,muddy shallow-marine limestoneswhich rapidly evolve into Chondrodonta-rich deposits with intra-bioclastic intercalations (Unit D6). These often display dm- to meter-scale, wedgeshaped geometries with erosive bases pointing to migration of lowrelief, shallow subtidal channels.
Following a further, seemingly long-term emersion phase accompanied by a well developed palaeokarstic system atop Unit D6, a rapid re-establishment of fully marine conditions is witnessed by the grain-supported, subtidal bioclastic and intrabioclastic limestones of Unit E.

sections.heading: 5.2. High-Resolution Event Stratigraphic (HIRES) correlation with the Mt. Faito reference section of the ApCP
sections.text:
The stratigraphic evolution of depositional and early diagenetic features described above (Section 4; Fig. 4) indicates that repeated environmental changes, dictated by high-frequency fluctuations of relative sea-level combinedwith short- and long-term hydroclimatic turnovers, played a fundamental role in controlling the sedimentation pattern of the Civitella Licinio section during a secular low-stand of sea level (Fig. 23).
The inner lagoonal carbonate strata with increasing occurrence of geopetally-filled dissolution cavities which alternate to lacustrine interlayers and lenses up to 35 cm thick suggest a reduced accommodation space on the platform in overall humid palaeohydrologic conditions (Unit D1; Fig. 7). The biogenic laminar calcrete beneath the uppermost lacustrine interval in the middle part of this Unit (see Section 4.1.1) points to the occurrence of a rapid (seasonal or multi-seasonal) arid snap during an overall wet phase (Fig. 23). A further, similar snap is embodied by relatively abundant pollens (Classopollis?) (cf. MejiaVelasquez et al., 2012) found in the uppermost Unit D1. These arid snaps are interpreted here as harbingers of the shift toward the relatively longer arid phase underlying the deposition of the following Units D2 andD3 (Fig. 23). As discussed in Section 5.1, in fact, the non-bioturbated microbialites with repeated subaerial exposures in the lowermost Unit D2 (Fig. 8) were formed under arid-semiarid conditions (cf. Husinec and Read, 2011) which accompanied also the deposition of the entire Unit D2 and, with much evidence, the overlying Plattenkalk with very abundant xeromorphic plants (Unit D3). It is worth to note that the observed S. dinarica acme preceded the climatic shift between Units D1 and D2–3 thus suggesting that it was deposited under wet hydroclimatic conditions (Fig. 23).
The restricted shallow-marine deposits of the lower Unit D4 testify to a short-term rise of the relative sea level. This part of the section yields shaley palaeosols and palaeokarstic features, which suggest renewed (seasonal?) humid conditions (e.g. Deconinck and Strasser, 1987) during a persisting, longer-term sea-level low stand. Low sea level and rapidly increasing moisture are documented by the brackish lime marls of the upper Unit D4 and, with much evidence, by the thick lacustrine carbonates of Unit D5 (Figs. 4, 5). Consistently, the intensity of chemical weathering affecting K-feldspar crystals matches the stratigraphic position of palaeoclimatic indicators (Fig. 22; Section 5.1), thus confirming a distinct cause-and-effect relationship.
Transgressive bivalve-rich limestones of Unit D6 terminate the lacustrine interval and testify to the gradual re-establishment of shallow-marine conditions in a persisting humid regime, as suggested by ephemeral emersions marked by thin greenish palaeosols (lowermiddle Unit D6).
The deep palaeokarst capping Unit D6 witnesses the last long-term subaerial exposure under a persisting humid regime.
The overall facies evolution described in the Civitella Licinio section matches the stratigraphic trend recorded by the Upper Aptian deposits of the ApCP (Mt. Faito, Mt. Tobenna and Serra Sbregavitelli sections) during a cooling episode and a long-term glacioeustatic lowstand (Graziano and Raspini, 2015). In the Mt. Faito reference section of the ApCP, several evaporite-rich intervals were deposited in a mudflatsaltern setting and, together with frequent transgressive shallowmarine interlayers, alternate quite regularly with lacustrine, paralic or very shallow-marine deposits suggestive of overall wetter conditions. Timing and duration of identified couplets of cyclic arid-wet phases (Fig. 23) have been determined at Mt. Faito by a cyclostratigraphically constrained age model tuned with deep-water Tethyan reference sections and suggest fluctuating hydroclimatic conditions over time scales of 100 and 400 ky (Graziano and Raspini, 2015).
Aiming at tuning the Civitella Licinio succession with the Mt. Faito reference section, several Upper Aptian lithologic and biostratigraphic key-markers have been taken into consideration. Results have been
reported in a HIRES framework to derive precise chronostratigraphic constraints which permit bed-to-bed correlations in the Upper Aptian of the ApCP ~70 km across (Fig. 23). The prominent lithologic key-marker is the base of thick brackish–lacustrine deposits (Units D4–5 at Civitella Licinio and uppermost Unit D at Mt. Faito) accounting for the onset of long-term humid conditions, which terminated previous high-frequency wet-arid fluctuations (Units D1–3 at Civitella Licinio and middle-upper Unit D at Mt. Faito). The regional-to-supraregional significance of these lithologies, indicative of persisting humid conditions in the late Gargasian, has been recently discussed in a Tethyan perspective (Graziano and Raspini, 2015). In fact, the lower boundary of this humid interval coincides with the development of the Polar Glacial Trigger at ~118.2 My (AlHusseini and Matthews, 2010), i.e. with the southward shrinking of the subtropical arid belt due to marked cooling of the Earth's hydrosphere–atmosphere system during the Late Aptian (cf. Graziano and Raspini, 2015). Consequently, the Frenelopsis-rich Plattenkalk herein (Unit D3) represents the local counterpart of the upper part of the third evaporite-rich interval at Mt. Faito (Fig. 23).
The lithologic boundary in betweenUnits D and E represents amajor lithologic key-marker in the upper part of the sections. It records the return to fullymarine conditions on the platform following the long-term, subaerial exposure under humid conditions documented by the underlying brackish–lacustrine interval (Units D4–5) and the deep palaeokarstic features capping Unit D6. At Mt. Faito, intense reworking processes and/or winnowing are recorded as ravinement breccias, about 2 m thick in the lowermost Unit E whose base has been dated astrochronologically at ~115 My (Graziano and Raspini, 2015). Therefore, the relatively long-lasting disconformity between Units D and E displays laterally a different stratigraphic signature (and time span?) being mainly diagenetic (deep palaeokarst) at Civitella Licinio and essentially erosive (shallow scoured surface) atMt. Faito (Fig. 23). In addition, a seemingly earlier, although short-lived, transgression is proven at Civitella Licinio by the bivalve-rich limestones of Unit D6. These deposits wedge out at Mt. Faito to punctuate the upper lacustrine interval of the uppermost Unit D in the formof cm-to-dm thick lenses of shallow marine limestones (previously disregarded by Graziano and Raspini, 2015). We believe that these deposits reflect the warming pulse documented by TEX86 palaeothermometry (McAnena et al., 2013) in the long-term cold phase of the Late Aptian (e.g. Maurer et al., 2013). An original chemostratigraphic tuning would attribute this thermal event to the latest (by reference to the GTS2012) or middle nolani zone (by reference to Graziano and Raspini, 2015) and to a numerical age of ~115.7 My (our unpublished data), thus shortening to b700 ky the erosional/non-depositional hiatus between Units D and E at Mt. Faito (formerly estimated as long as 2.5 My by Graziano and Raspini, 2015). Hence: 1) the shallow-marine Unit D6 and the capping, deep palaeokarst at Civitella Licinio are coeval with the uppermost lacustrine deposits which end Unit D at Mt. Faito; and 2) the Gargasian– Clansayesian boundary (corresponding to ~116.8 My in the GTS2012, cf. Ogg and Hinnov, 2012) would fall within Unit D5 as this latter straddles the melchioris–nolani boundary zone (Fig. 23).
Despite a certain degree of chronostratigraphic uncertainty, we hypothesize that the disconformity between Units D and E at Civitella Licinio and at Mt. Faito likely corresponds to the deep erosional surface underlying the cross-bedded, coarse bioclastic and litho/intraclastic rudstone on top of the Pietraroja section described by Ruberti et al. (2013). These sediments were deposited during an early structuring phase as demonstrated by dm-to-m-scale neptunian dykes and synsedimentary faults (Carannante et al., 2006). The compared stratigraphic architecture and evolving facies trend (i.e., differential rates of shallowing and deepening) together with field evidence (e.g. Fig. 9) imply a consistent pattern of regional tectonic subsidence inducing contemporaneous block faulting and local uplift during the widespread synsedimentary extensional tectonics which affected the ApCP in the Late Aptian (e.g., Carannante et al., 2009; Graziano and Raspini, 2015).
A further, reliable key-marker for high-resolution correlations is the S. dinarica acme in the uppermost Unit D1, i.e. at the end of a short-term humid interlude (Fig. 23). This acme cannot be correlated with the lower S. dinarica acme of the ApCP which, by contrast, was deposited earlier than the Orbitolina Level and, above all, during an arid episode (as far as its topmost part is concerned) (Fig. 23). Crucial to this issue, we reappraise here the densely packed S. dinarica level which sharply overlies the second evaporite-rich interval at Mt. Faito (Graziano and Raspini, 2015) as the upper S. dinarica acmeof theApCP. Its stratigraphic position, with respect to the Orbitolina Level, as well as hydroclimatic significance fit those of the S. dinarica acme at Civitella Licinio. Therefore: A) the lower S. dinarica acme (a few meters below the Orbitolina Level) begins in the uppermost Lower Aptian (furcata ammonite zone) and would terminate in the lower Upper Aptian (lowermost Gargasian, lower subnodosocostatum/martinoides ammonite zone), according to Di Lucia et al. (2012), or in the middle Upper Aptian (upper Gargasian, upper martinoides ammonite zone) according to Graziano and Raspini (2015); and B) the upper S. dinarica acme (a few meters above the Orbitolina Level) falls in the uppermost martinoides ammonite zone (Fig. 23).
Based on the bed-to-bed correlations above, the following results are put forward (Fig. 23) (cf. also see Graziano and Raspini, 2015):
- Unit D1 was deposited during a wet phase from 118.60 to 118.40 My. - The age of the upper S. dinarica acme of the ApCP (uppermost Unit D1) is comprised in the late (?) time interval between 118.60 and 118.50 My (lowermost Superbundle T4 at Mt. Faito–Mt. Tobenna). - The Frenelopsis-rich Plattenkalk (Unit D3) was formed during the latest arid phase in the late Gargasian of the ApCP, i.e. between ~118.30 and 118.20–10 My, and represent the lateral equivalent of the upper part of the 3rd evaporite interval at Mt. Faito. - The brackish to lacustrine Units D4–5 and the shallow marine Unit D6 are the lateral equivalent of the thick lacustrine deposits of the Mt. Faito and Mt. Tobenna sections. They prove the long-lasting (~3.5 My) establishment of a late Gargasian–early Clansayesian fresh-water setting which replaced a playa like-desert on the ApCP, following the onset of the Glacial Trigger at ~118.2/118.1 My. - The return to fully marine conditions on the local platform (Unit E) shortly precedes the LAD of S. dinarica and occurred starting in the middle Clansayesian at ~115 My, in the lower jacobi (following GST2012; Ogg and Hinnov, 2012) or in the reappraised latest nolani zone. - The chronostratigraphic distribution of pyroclastic grains in the Civitella Licinio section encompasses at least 2.6 My, from uppermost Unit D2 to Unit D5. Furthermore, by considering former results on the Orbitolina Level key-marker (Bravi and De Castro, 1995; Mondillo et al., 2011) as well as its numerical age of 118.8– 118.7 My (Graziano and Raspini, 2015), tephras have been supplied almost continuously to the ApCP as long as ~3 My during the late Gargasian–early Clansayesian.

sections.heading: 5.3. Late Aptian volcanism: insights from the Civitella Licinio section
5.3.1. Palaeogeographic and palaeoclimatic implications
sections.text:
During the ~2.6 My time span of the uppermost Unit D2–Unit D5 (Fig. 23), the Civitella Licinio section has been punctuated by repeated volcanic inputs, documented by frequent glass shards and abundant K-feldspar crystals (see Section 4.3) that we consider here to be constituted by the sanidine polymorph. In fact, a diagenetic or detrital origin of the K-feldspar crystals (eventually providing microcline or orthoclase, respectively) are to be ruled out according to the following, independent sedimentologic, taphonomic, diagenetic–petrographic and palaeogeographic lines of evidence: 1) lack of abrasion induced by an eventual transport in fluvial or eolian settings; 2) absence of a
structured drainage system in an arid/sub-arid setting (uppermost Unit D2 and Unit D3) or an effective transport in a supposed erg-like environment (never documented in the whole ApCP); 3) the very finegrained glass shards and K-feldspar crystals (3–30 μm in size) are consistent with the distance from the inferred, faraway volcanic source (see below); 4) Frenelopsis remains, which are associated with volcanic grains throughout the Plattenkalk, display evident parautochthonous depositional conditions; 5) crystals are euhedral to subhedral, even in the case of the variably intense chemical weathering, and ensuing formation of clayminerals, that has been observed in scattered stratigraphic intervals; and 6) the epi-oceanic nature of the ApCP and its palaeogeographic position well apart from any source of sediments from exposed basement rocks.
We do not at the moment have precise insights in the field into the spatial arrangement of the volcanic grains within the Plattenkalk sediments, although SEM investigationwould allowhypothesizing the presence of some discrete ash layers. This possibly relies on the low preservation potential of the original, presumably very thin ash fall deposits (see below) in a highly unstable coastal mudflat owing to effective wind erosion and soil bioturbation by vegetation cover. On the other hand, the arid conditions at the time of the windblown supply of the pyroclastic material on the emerged ApCP favored their preservation from intense chemical weathering, as observed in the Plattenkalk deposits (Unit D3). By contrast, a severe chemical weathering has been effectively observed on the sanidine crystals found in the brackish and lacustrine deposits (upper Unit D4 and Unit D5) (Fig. 22), the latter yielding evidence of very thin ash layers resulting from particle fallout and preservation in a presumably shallow lake (see Section 4.3).
The evidence of explosive, possibly subduction-related volcanic activity provides further information on chronostratigraphic, palaeogeographic and palaeoclimatic reconstructions at the start of a major geodynamic phase in the Tethyan Realm. The Late Aptian, in fact, is a crucial interval at the onset of a rapid reorganization of the pery-Tethyan plates as well as of a new migration pattern of plate boundaries following magnetozone M0 (Rosenbaum et al., 2002; Stampfli and Hochard, 2009; Schettino and Turco, 2011). Between 121 and 112 My, the wander path of the terranes involved in the early Alpine orogeny changed markedly, thus originating, among others, an active orogenic margin in the Transdanubian and North Calcareous domains as well as the development of the Vardar intra-oceanic back-arc system (Stampfli and Hochard, 2009). Thus, the generation of the Austroalpine orogenic wedge in the Late Aptian (Froitzheim et al., 1996) and its northwestward migration following the Piemonte– Penninic ocean rollback (Rosenbaum and Lister, 2005) resulted in the formation of the Vardar arc–trench system and orogenic volcanism in the NW Balkan orogen (Stampfli and Hochard, 2009) (Fig. 24). This major orogenic event in the evolving framework of the Austroalpine phase was sealed by Albian–Cenomanian molasse-type sediments (Stampfli and Kozur, 2006) and seemingly represents the best genetic cause of the Late Aptian explosive volcanismdocumented in the studied Civitella Licinio section.
Pyroclastic material, in fact, is typically formed by explosive volcanism at arc–trench systems and may represent a conspicuous source of sediments (tephra) in terrestrial, shallow- and deep-water settings, as well as a crucial tool for correlating faraway sections. Notable examples for the Cretaceous are given, among others, by Christiansen et al. (1994) and Bernoulli et al. (2004). Despite that a number of variables are involved in the production, dispersal and deposition of tephra, major grain size parameters (mode, median and sorting) of pyroclastic fragments are a reliable proxy for evaluating the distance between depositional sites and the imputed centers of volcanic emission (e.g. Fisher, 1964; Engwell et al., 2014). Although a quantitative granulometric analysis on the very fine-grained sanidine crystals and glass shards from the investigated Plattenkalk and the encasing units has not been performed, we observe that: 1) the minimum grain size of the observed tephra particles (~3 μm) would be also compatible
with the minimum limit for pyroclastic comminution of ~2 μm (Fisher, 1964); and 2) the plot of their modal class (15–20 μm) within a ‘grain size (95th percentile)’ versus ‘distance from source’ diagram for a reference, extreme explosive event (Campanian ignimbrite; Engwell et al., 2014) would point to an emission center located at about 1400–1500 km. This value would be consistent with the possible provenance of volcanic ash from the Dinaridic–Carpatho-Balkan magmatic province and the trade wind pattern for the Late Aptian of the northern low latitudes (Fig. 24). In fact, the position of the volcanic source may be palaeogeographically constrained by the analysis of the wind pattern for the Late Aptian as the areal extent and palaeogeographic distribution of windblown volcanic ash generally mirrors the wind pattern in the troposphere (e.g. Elder, 1988). Hay (2008) and Chaboureau et al. (2012), among others, provide reliable information on this issue as their atmospheric circulation models clarify the Late Aptian trade wind pattern and intensity at an unprecedented resolution level. These models invariably pinpoint the central role exerted by the low-latitude easterlies connecting the Dinaridic– Carpatho-Balkan explosive volcanism and the subaerially exposed carbonate platforms of the central Western Tethys during the Late Aptian glacio-eustatic lowstand (synthesis in Graziano and Raspini, 2015) (Fig. 24). These same trade winds have also been claimed to identify the source area of further volcanic ash fall layers from slope and pelagic carbonate sections of Campanian age in the Apennines (central Italy) and the Gargano region (southern Italy) (Graziano and Adabbo, 1996; Bernoulli et al., 2004).

sections.heading: 5.3.2. Tephrostratigraphy
sections.text:
Our findings extend further the inventory of the volcanic ash layers found in the Aptian–Turonian of the ApCP as well as other shallowwater domains of the Western Tethys. Bravi and De Castro (1995) first reported the presence of augitic pyroxenes in the Upper Aptian Orbitolina Level of the Mt. Faito reference section. Recent investigation carried out by Mondillo et al. (2011) on the Orbitolina Level of the Mt. Tobenna section (about 34 km and 70 km apart Mt. Faito and Civitella Licinio, respectively; Fig. 1) have revealed the presence of windblown volcanic zircon, monazite, rutile and ilmenite. This mineral association is markedly similar to that found in the middle Albian– Cenomanian bauxites of the Matese Mts. whose geochemical investigation, coupled to palaeogeographic considerations, has pinpointed, again, a windblown origin from the orogenic Dinaridic and Carpatho-Balkan explosive volcanism (Boni et al., 2012). A similar source, with the possible additional input from African craton protoliths, has been suggested by geochemical investigation (Mongelli et al., 2014) on the Turonian, tectonically-controlled bauxitiferous unconformity (e.g. Mindszenty et al., 1995) of the Apulia carbonate platform (SE Italy).
Tephrostratigraphic correlation of the increasing number of ash layers signaled in the Upper Aptian of the Tethys and adjoining regions (e.g. Ruffell et al., 2002; Beaudoin et al., 2012; Boni et al., 2012; and study herein), significantly improves our understanding of Tethyan palaeogeography, geodynamics and palaeoclimate. In this light, we observe that the intervals with pyroclastic fragments found in the upper Gargasian and lower Clansayesian of the Civitella Licinio section (uppermost Unit D2–Unit D5) and in the Orbitolina Level of the ApCP can be roughly correlated with the Matisse and Van Gogh bentonites, respectively, of the Vocontian Basin (VB) (Friés and Parize, 2003; Beaudoin et al., 2012, and references therein). Whether these intervals can be also physically correlated depends on several types of uncertainties with calibration among biostratigraphic zonations, high-resolution correlation of available chemostratigraphy for the neritic Upper Aptian of the ApCP (cf. Di Lucia et al., 2012; Raspini, 2012), and rescaling of stratigraphic data anchored to different Global Time Scales (GTSs). For instance, the two bentonite horizons of the Matisse level fall in the (lower?) melchioris ammonite zone (Beaudoin et al., 2012) whereas the Civitella Licinio sanidine- and glass shard-bearing uppermost Unit D2 and Unit D3 are the equivalent of the upper 3rd evaporite interval
at Mt. Faito (Section 5.2) and, hence, fall in the uppermost martinoides zone of the GTS2012 (Graziano and Raspini, 2015) (Fig. 23). Rather, the pyroclastic materials of the brackish–lacustrine Units D4–D5, the latter being the equivalent of the uppermost Unit D at Mt. Faito, fall in the lowermost melchioris zone of the GTS2012 (Graziano and Raspini, 2015) and, hence, represent the best possible equivalent of the Matisse level, despite that the upper part of Unit D5 and thewhole Unit D6 possibly extend to the upper (?) nolani zone (Fig. 23) (see Section 5.2).
A critical issue concerning the proposed tephra correlation between the ApCP and the VB relies on the alleged emission center of the slightly younger, latest Aptian Cézanne bentonite found in the jacobi zone of the VB and tentatively correlated with the Wöhrum ash layer from the Lower Saxony basin in Northern Germany (Beaudoin et al., 2012). This latter, in fact, has been supposed to reflect the volcanic activity in the Waddenzee area (offshore Holland) (Mutterlose et al., 2003), i.e., about 1200 km north of the VB (Fig. 24). Although identifying a specific volcanic source for tephra layers is usually problematic, the analysis of the trade wind pattern for the Late Aptian seems to rule out such a northern source of the Cézanne tephra and, conversely, to support an eastern provenance from the Dinaridic and Carpatho-Balkan explosive volcanism (Fig. 24). Testing these hypotheses requires detailed chronostratigraphic and geochemical studies on Upper Aptian tephra that, however, are beyond the scope of this paper.
Nonetheless, the observation that some of the recognized bentonite levels from the VB and UMB underlie or coincide with the major late Aptian black shale episodes of the Western Tethys (namely the Fallot and Jacob OAEs) makes it possible to envisage an intriguing and previously disregarded positive feedback mechanism of the complex causeand-effect relationships underlying their formation. In fact, the remarkable fertilization potential of surface waters by volcanic ashes and the consequent forcing of the biogeochemical cycling of carbon and biolimiting metals are well-known features of present-day oceans (e.g. Frogner et al., 2001; Duggen et al., 2010; Lindenthal et al., 2013). Such a relationship can be likely proposed for the FallotOAE, given its chronostratigraphic and physical correlationwith theOrbitolina Level (Raspini, 2012; Graziano and Raspini, 2015) and the related tephra layer (layers?).
On the whole, the observations and hypotheses above reinforce the suitability of the Aptian record as a reference proxy for deciphering the present-day and future evolution of the Earth's hydro-, bio- atmosphere system (e.g. Hay, 2011; Hay and Floegel, 2012).

sections.heading: 6. Summary and conclusions
sections.text:
This paper provides a contribution to the stratigraphic and palaeoclimatic comprehension as well as the palaeobotany of the Upper Aptian of the Apennine Carbonate Platform (ApCP) (southern Italy) by applying an integrated correlation technique and a palaeoenvironmental reconstruction based on lithofacies indicators of wet (characean-rich limestones/marls) versus arid-semiarid (supratidal microbialites, calcrete and Frenelopsis-rich palaeosols) phases as well as early diagenetic features (geopetal infills/palaeokarst vs desiccation cracks). By integrating the stratigraphic data herein and previous studies on the stratigraphy, astrochronology and palaeoclimatic evolution of the ApCP recorded by the Mt. Faito reference section (Graziano and Raspini, 2015), the following conclusions can be drawn:
- The Civitella Licinio section (upper Gargasian–middle Clansayesian) has recorded the stratigraphic effects of the well-known Late Aptian glacio-eustatic lowstand and preserves evidence of short-term hydroclimatic fluctuations in the form of meter-scale intercalations of lacustrine lithofacies that straddle a plant-rich Plattenkalk which was deposited in a supratidal-to-paralic coastal mudflat under an overall arid climatic regime. - The upper S. dinarica acme of the ApCP was deposited during a brief humid interlude between ~118.55 and 118.50 My (by reference to
the GTS2012). Hence, a striking euryhaline character may be attributed to S. dinarica as the top of its lower acme (119–118.9 My atMt. Faito) occurred during an interval of evident arid conditions (first evaporite-rich level). - The Frenelopsis-rich Plattenkalk was deposited between 118.3 and 118.2–118.1 My and represents the lateral equivalent of the upper part of the third evaporite-rich interval at Mt. Faito. The resulting composite layer, representing the transition between a paralic mudflat and a restricted, hypersaline shallow lagoon on the emerged ApCP was deposited under arid conditions prior to the onset of a major shift to a persisting humid regime at ~118.2 My (Glacial Trigger). - Common to frequent pyroclastic fragments (glass shards and sanidine crystals) have been documented in the upper Gargasian– lower Clansayesian of the Civitella Licinio section during a ~2.6 My time interval from the uppermost martinoides to the upper nolani ammonite zones (sensu GTS2012). Pattern and intensity of the variable, early chemical weathering matches the rapidly fluctuating hydroclimatic conditions on the ApCP. - The seemingly monogeneric presence of the conifer Frenelopsis sp. throughout the Plattenkalk suggests that this genus was possibly the main component of the palaeo-biocoenosis. Possibly, tephra favored the preservation of the material along the section studied. Plant remains possibly represent a stable biotope, as floral composition presents no variation along the section studied. Moreover, sedimentological and palaeobotanical data confirm that the Plattenkalk formed during an arid period. High temperatures and lightning strikes generated wildfire as is testified by the abundance of fusain in the Civitella Licinio section. Frenelopsis from Civitella Licinio lived in an area subjected to repeated volcanic ash falls. - The stratigraphic, palaeoenvironmental and hydroclimatic evolution recorded by the Civitella Licinio and Mt. Faito sections (~70 km apart) are perfectly in phase, thus confirming the overwhelming role of supra-regional controlling mechanisms on the short- and long-term (100 and 400 ky, as derived by the astrochronology of Mt. Faito section) palaeoclimatic evolutions even at a regional scale. - The unusual, coupled proliferation of solitary corals and siliceous sponges in the restricted, very shallow marine embayment heralding the deposition of the Frenelopsis-rich Plattenkalk seems to rely on the environmental pollution related to the pyroclastic supply. This was presumably sourced by the explosive volcanism connected with the developing Carpatho-Balkan orogen and transported toward the ApCP, i.e. ~1400 km across, by northeasterly trade winds. Preliminary, tephrostratigraphic correlations in the Upper Aptian of the ApCP and Vocontian Basin are proposed.
This study demonstrates that facies analysis and High-Resolution Event Stratigraphy (HIRES) may disentangle the physical (bed-to-bed) correlation of faraway, typically discontinuous continental and marginal marine successions when an integrated sedimentological, astrochronological and palaeoclimatic analysis is employed. Such an approachmay virtually overcome the failure of carbon and oxygen isotope chemostratigraphy in the correlation of interlayered continental and shallow-marine successions as a consequence of early diagenetic biases which typically affect the related sedimentary record.

abstractText: Editor: Dr. B. Jones This study reports an integrated facies analysis carried out on a new section from the Upper Aptian of the SE Matese Mts. (Civitella Licinio, northern Campania, S. Italy), which includes several decimeter-to-meter scale lacustrine intervals straddling a meter-scale plant-rich Plattenkalk. These intervals are assigned to the late Gargasian–early Clansayesian by their stratigraphic relationship with the upper Salpingoporella dinarica acme as well as lithologic and biostratigraphic supra-regional key-markers found in the Apennine Carbonate Platform (ApCP), including the Orbitolina Level. We infer that the monogeneric parautochthonous plant remains (Frenelopsis sp.) were deposited in a supratidal-to-paralic coastal mudflat close to a restricted, shallow-marine lagoon, at the verge of an arid–semiarid climatic phase. The Plattenkalk was rapidly replaced by persistent lacustrine lithofacies at the onset of amajor climatic turnover (Glacial Trigger). The overlying shallow-marine deposits are capped by a deeply incised palaeokarstic surface and, in turn, by unconformable middle Clansayesian transgressive shallow-marine deposits. Interlayering of reliable lithologic indicators of palaeoclimate and High-Resolution Event Stratigraphic (HIRES) correlation of the Civitella Licinio succession with the astrochronologically tuned Mt. Faito reference section of the ApCP bring evidence of rapidly fluctuating hydroclimatic conditions (wet and arid phases) in the short (100 ky) and long (400 ky) eccentricity time band. HIRES and astrochronological age assignment to crucial key markers and humid/arid phases at Civitella Licinio permit to further refine the detailed stratigraphy of the Mt. Faito reference section and to assign the upper S. dinarica acme of the ApCP to a numerical age of 118.55– 118.50 My. SEM and EDS analyses document common to abundant windblown volcanic particles (glass shards and sanidine crystals) throughout the Frenelopsis-rich Plattenkalk (~118.3 to ~118.2 My) and the encasing units, especially in the overlying brackish–lacustrine deposits. Palaeogeographic and palaeoclimatic reconstructions suggest that the pyroclastic material was probably transported by northeasterly trade winds from orogenic volcanic centers located within the Dinaridic–Carpatho-Balkan arc–trench system and have been supplied to the ApCP for a time span of ~3My during the Late Aptian. A preliminary tephrostratigraphic correlation of the Upper Aptian volcaniclastic levels of the ApCP with the bentonite levels of the Vocontian Basin is proposed. © 2016 Elsevier B.V.
